thread.title_full: Rocket Internet plans to sell its top companies in India - The Times of India

author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: Rocket Internet plans to sell its top companies in India -
text:
NEW DELHI/BENGALURU: Rocket Internet, once a high-flying progenitor of Indian e-commerce startups, is considering a plan to sell its top companies here, multiple people aware of the matter said, marking a big shift in strategy for the German firm. 

Instead of incubating startups, the founders of Rocket Internet will now invest directly in companies through a venture capital fund, which analysts said reflected the failure of its model as well as the promise of the opportunity in India. 

Fashion retailer Jabong, food services aggregator Foodpanda and furniture retailer FabFurnish are on the block, sources said, with these once-dominant Rocket Internet ventures losing significant ground to a rush of nimbler rivals amid an unceasing churn in their operations. 

Present and former Rocket Internet entrepreneurs, investors and analysts confirmed the developments, but declined to be identified citing professional relationships with the Berlin-based incubator and investor, or with their ventures in India. 

Rocket Internet spokesman Jan Christoph Bohnerth said the company would not comment on what he said were "rumors." Foodpanda India chief executive Saurabh Kochhar said, "Rocket Internet continues to believe in the Indian internet consumer market. We will continue to be invested." 

Global Founders Capital, a European investment firm founded by Rocket Internet CEO Oliver Samwer and his brothers and Fidelity Growth Partners Europe alum Daniel Jones, has already begun investing in India. Kochhar said GFC is a 100% subsidiary of Rocket Internet. 

In April, the venture capital firm participated in an $18-million funding round in Craftsvilla, an online marketplace for ethnic products, and three months later invested in Bengaluru-based automotive services marketplace Cartisan. 

Rocket Internet maintains a stronghold over its companies, operating these through founders who take key decisions based on directions from the incubator's headquarters in Berlin. Experts said while this model has worked for Rocket Internet in other markets, it hobbles companies operating in India's highly competitive startup industry. 

In the past year, startups such as TinyOwl and Swiggy have emerged with business models rivaling Rocket Internet companies in India, and securing huge sums from investors. Established consumer internet companies including Flipkart, Snapdeal and Amazon are also rapidly adding segments such as fashion and furniture, competing with Jabong and FabFurnish. 

"Rocket Internet just failed to anticipate the depth of competition in India. The internet business in India is a different beast altogether," said a former senior executive at a Rocket Internet company in India. 

India's online retail industry is estimated to grow at a 47% compounded annual growth rate to $47 billion (about Rs 3 lakh crore) in the next five years, according to a report by Goldman Sachs. 

Flipkart commands 44% of India's e-commerce market, Snapdeal 32%, and Amazon India 15%, according to a recent Morgan Stanley report, leaving Jabong battling it out with new entrants such as Tiger Global-backed Shopclues for the scraps. Amazon earlier this year called off a proposed deal to buy Jabong. 

"(Rocket Internet's) model of owning 90% of a venture simply doesn't motivate the founders, who, for obvious reasons, are not going to have the same values as that of Narayana Murthy or a Nandan Nilekani. The risk is imminent," said a fund manager. 

Four of five founder-managing directors of Jabong so far have quit, and Foodpanda India, which now also competes with Zomato's new online ordering business, continues to see a steady revolving door involving its top management. At FabFurnish, which competes with larger rivals Urban Ladder and PepperFry, founders Mehul Aggrawal and Vikram Chopra have step down from managing day-to-day operations. 

Rocket Internet has continued to pump money into its Indian ventures but not at the scale of some of its peers. 

In February last year, Jabong raised about $100 million from a consortium of investors including Swedish investment giant AB Kinnevik and Rocket Internet. This pales in comparison with the $3.4 billion that Flipkart has raised in total, and Snapdeal's $1.6 billion equity financing overall. Amazon is readying a $5-billion war-chest for its Indian unit.
